metadata.name: Persian Hovering Garden
metadata.description:
Persian garden is an archetype that lies at the root of myths, rituals, faiths and beliefs of Iranian people. Eden as ancient Iranians imagined it, had seven fences in a row one of which in the middle was wider and higher than the others such that Devil could not find its way through it (for instance in the margin of the Persian carpet). This Iranian paradise had a source of water which was eternal, always flowing in it, dividing the garden into four sectors. At the intersection of these four gardens (Chahar Bagh) was placed a beautiful pavilion in architecture and a bergamot (Toranj) in Persian carpet which is considered as the center of the garden world.
The first Persian garden that David Stronach first explored was built in Pasargadae by Cyrus the Great (Achaemenid era); An enclosed garden, long, with pavilions with open porches on four sides and a water runnel in between.
